## Scatterplot

The following example from the seaborn gallery shows gas consumption
(miles per gallon) given horsepower for a series of cars based on the
[`mpg`](https://github.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/blob/master/mpg.csv) data set
using custom colors from the HCL-based qualitative color palette "Dark 3".

```{python seaborn_example_1}
#| warning: true
#| error: true

from colorspace import qualitative_hcl
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
sns.set_theme(style="white")

# Load the example mpg dataset
mpg = sns.load_dataset("mpg")

# Colors to be used
pal = qualitative_hcl("Dark 3").colors(3)

# Plot miles per gallon against horsepower with other semantics
sns.relplot(x = "horsepower", y = "mpg", hue = "origin", size = "weight", 
            sizes = (40, 400), alpha = .5, palette = pal,
            height = 6, data = mpg)
plt.show()
```


## Multi-group histogram

The next example shows a 'multi group' distribution plot (`kind = "kde"`)
based on the [`penguins`](https://github.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/blob/master/penguins.csv)
data set using, again, a series of colors from the sequential HCL-based
color palette "Dark 3".

```{python seaborn_example_2}
#| warning: true
#| error: true

from colorspace import qualitative_hcl 
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns 

# Loading penguins data set
penguins = sns.load_dataset("penguins")

# Creating plot
sns.displot(data=penguins, x = "flipper_length_mm",                           
        hue = "species", fill = "species", kind = "kde", rug = True, 
        palette = qualitative_hcl("Dark 3").colors(3))                  
plt.show()
```

## Heatmap

HCL-based color maps (`LinearSegmentedColormap` objects) can directly
be used for seaborn heatmaps, here using the sequential HCL-based 'yellow-orange-red'
("YlOrRd") palette in reversed order (`rev = True`).

```{python seaborn_example_3}
#| warning: true
#| error: true

from colorspace import sequential_hcl
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 
# Simulate data from a bivariate Gaussian 
n    = 10000 
mean = [0, 0] 
cov  = [(2, .4), (.4, .2)] 
rng  = np.random.RandomState(0) 
x, y = rng.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, n).T 
 
# Draw heatmap
sns.histplot(x = x, y = y, bins = 50, pthresh = .1,             
             cmap = sequential_hcl("YlOrRd", rev = True).cmap())
plt.show()
```

Besides the pre-definec palettes, fully customized color maps can
be defined and used for plotting, here reversing the color palette
using matplotlibs `.reversed()` method.

```{python seaborn_example_3_1}
#| warning: true
#| error: true

from colorspace import sequential_hcl
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create fully customized HCL-based sequential palette
custom_cmap = sequential_hcl(h = [330, 170], c = [45, 70, 10],
                             l = [25, 95], power = [0.5, 1.5]).cmap().reversed()

# Draw heatmap
sns.histplot(x = x, y = y, bins = 50, pthresh = .1,             
             cmap = custom_cmap)
plt.show()
```
